H0.text: Hot spots are where most of the volcanoes that make up the “Ring of Fire” were formed.

H1.text: Subduction zones are where most of the volcanoes that make up the “Ring of Fire” were formed.

H2.text: Divergent boundaries are where most of the volcanoes that make up the Ring of Fire were formed.

H3.text: Normal faults are the features near which most of the volcanoes that make up the Ring of Fire were formed.

A4.text: The Ring of Fire is not a single geological structure. It was created by the subduction of different tectonic plates at convergent boundaries around the Pacific Ocean.

A5.text: The Ring of Fire has existed for more than 35 million years but subduction has existed for much longer in some parts of the Ring; many older extinct volcanoes are located within the Ring.
